situations.name: At the Café
situations.description: Cafes are social hubs in Saigon. Ordering confidently in Vietnamese will earn you smiles and sometimes free upgrades to your drink.
situations.culturalNote: Vietnamese coffee culture is sacred. Taking time to sit and sip is expected—rushing is seen as odd. Sidewalk cafes with tiny plastic stools are often better than fancy ones.

phrases.whenToUse: Your essential coffee order—this is the default
phrases.culturalTip: This is Southern Vietnamese iced coffee with condensed milk. It's sweet, strong, and addictive.

phrases.whenToUse: If you want coffee without milk
phrases.culturalTip: Add 'đá' (da) for iced, 'nóng' (nong) for hot

phrases.whenToUse: When your drink needs more ice in the heat
phrases.culturalTip: Ice is free and plentiful—asking for more is normal
This phrase makes people smile instantly

situations.name: In a Taxi / Grab
situations.description: Most rides are via Grab app now, but knowing these phrases helps with communication and shows respect.
situations.culturalNote: Grab is everywhere and safe. Traditional taxis can overcharge tourists—use the meter or stick with Grab. Drivers appreciate any Vietnamese attempt.

phrases.culturalTip: Have the address written in Vietnamese or show on phone

phrases.whenToUse: When you've arrived or want to stop
phrases.culturalTip: Point as you say it for clarity

phrases.whenToUse: Asking the price (though Grab shows it upfront)
phrases.culturalTip: With Grab you don't need this, but useful for traditional taxis
Use 'anh' for male drivers, 'chị' (chee) for female drivers

situations.name: At a Restaurant
situations.description: Street food stalls and local restaurants are where Vietnamese shines. These phrases will enhance your eating experience immensely.
situations.culturalNote: Pointing at menu items or what others are eating is totally acceptable. Food culture is casual and welcoming. Don't expect fast service—meals are social, not rushed.

phrases.whenToUse: Ordering food at stalls or restaurants
phrases.culturalTip: Point at what you want as you say this

phrases.whenToUse: If you can't handle heat—VERY useful
phrases.culturalTip: Vietnamese food isn't super spicy compared to Thai, but this helps
May need to call the server over first with 'Em ơi!' (em oy - excuse me)

phrases.whenToUse: Complimenting the food—makes vendors incredibly happy
phrases.culturalTip: This phrase creates instant warmth and often leads to conversations
Point at the dish and ask—people love explaining their food

situations.name: Greetings & Politeness
situations.description: Vietnamese greetings depend on age and gender. These basics will serve you well and show respect.
situations.culturalNote: Age hierarchy is important in Vietnam. Using the right pronoun (anh/chi/em) shows cultural awareness and earns respect. When in doubt, use anh (for men) or chi (for women) for people who look older than you.

phrases.whenToUse: General greeting, safe in any situation
phrases.culturalTip: Add 'anh' (male) or 'chị' (female) after for more respect: 'Xin chào anh'
Can add 'nhiều' (nyew) for 'thank you very much': Cảm ơn nhiều
Works for both 'sorry' and 'excuse me'—context makes it clear
Literally means 'no star' but means 'no worries'—very common phrase
More casual: 'Chào anh/chị' (just 'chao an/chee') works for bye too

situations.name: Shopping & Markets
situations.description: Markets are social spaces. Bargaining is expected in some (like Ben Thanh) but not all. These phrases help navigate.
situations.culturalNote: Bargaining is an art in Vietnam. Smile, be friendly, and don't be aggressive. Fixed-price shops are becoming more common, especially in malls. When in doubt, ask if price can be negotiated.

phrases.culturalTip: First price at tourist markets is often 2-3x actual—bargain politely

phrases.whenToUse: When bargaining—say it with a smile
phrases.culturalTip: Part of the dance—they expect this response
Works better than demanding—Vietnamese appreciate politeness

phrases.whenToUse: When you've agreed on a price
phrases.culturalTip: Point at the item as you say it

situations.name: Emergency & Help
situations.description: Hope you never need these, but knowing them provides peace of mind.
situations.culturalNote: Vietnamese people are generally very helpful to foreigners in distress. Don't hesitate to ask for help—'Xin lỗi' (excuse me) followed by simple English often works too.

phrases.culturalTip: Wave your arms, look distressed—people will assist
Show Google Translate or point to phone—hospitals have English speakers
Pointing and saying 'WC' also works—universal sign

phrases.whenToUse: When you can't find your way
phrases.culturalTip: Show your phone with destination—people will help or call you a Grab
